--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Eric Armstrong <eric.armstrong@s...> wrote:
> "Mike Colbert " wrote:
> 
> >  One technique we use, with Java, is to implement our JUnit 
> > TestCases as static inner classes.
[...]
> This sounds like a really great idea.

Sorry, but it's not.

<aside>
Hmm.. how very Canadian of me.  I'm not really sorry at all.  It works
much better when you don't have TestCases tied tightly to classes
being tested.
</aside>

TestCases and Classes being tested should have only coincedental
correspondance.  A TestCase is the embodiment of a *fixture*... a
specific context in which tests are run.  As such it should contain
only those tests (i.e. test methods) which run in the context of the
fixture that the TestCase embodies.
 
And, anyway, tests are meant to test behavior,not classes.

> I only recently became enamored of JUnit, as a result of 
> JUnitDoclet's creating a test framework for me. That shortened the 
> JUnit learning curve, which helped a lot.

As I said above (and will again, watch for a CoadLetter issue on the
topic) there should be no explicit coorelation between classes being
tested and TestCase subclasses.

> I'm curious. Do you know of any IDEs that support this technique by
> generating static inner test classes?

Well, Together does.  You can point it at a class and have it generate
a skeletal TestCase.  This is, IMO, at best useless, and at worst
disastereous.

Dave
